item.title: How to turn a napkin sketch into a web page
item.description:
Mckay Wrigley on Twitter

‚ÄúGreg Brockman (@gdb) of OpenAI just demoed GPT-4 creating a working website from an image of a sketch from his notebook. It‚Äôs the coolest thing I‚Äôve *ever* seen in tech. If you extrapolate from that demo, the possibilities are endless. A glimpse into the future of computing.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/mckaywrigley/status/1635740909383061504?s=20

source: Wednesday assorted links

item.title: Data center used to heat swimming pool
item.description:
Zoe Kleinman on Twitter

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been working on this story for some time. I spoke to physicists & environmental engineers to make sure that it really could work on a practical level. I went back & forth with Deep Green for detailed info about their system‚Ä¶. https://t.co/Tj8N1ZZ1p4‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/zsk/status/1635559865245466625

item.title: Running cognitive pipelines on cheap hardware
item.description:
Artem Andreenko üá∫üá¶ on Twitter

‚ÄúI‚Äôve sucefully runned LLaMA 7B model on my 4GB RAM Raspberry Pi 4. It‚Äôs super slow about 10sec/token. But it looks we can run powerful cognitive pipelines on a cheap hardware.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/miolini/status/1634982361757790209?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email

item.title: additive prompting
item.description:
Nick St. Pierre on Twitter

‚Äúok, I got ChatGPT working with Additive Prompting Here‚Äôs a 1 paragraph ChatGPT prompt you can use to generate infinite interior design/architecture photographs w/ 90%+ coherence to the prompt in Midjourney Full prompt w/ examples in thread. Try reading the prompts as you go üßµ‚Äù

Jason Furman on Twitter
